channel.title: iOS Development - How?
channel.description: So I'd like to develop for iOS/Android. But it seems Apple (being all high and mighty) has made it so that you can only use [b]their IDE[/b] which just happens to only be on [b]their OS[/b]. Now, people say that you could just get a VM and develop that way, which is rather obnoxious, or you could go buy OSX. But is there a third way to develop of the iOS. Android is open and no issue, the only problem is conversions. Still, I'm more worried about iOS and Apple's lockdown.

item.title: iOS Development - How?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

Or just use HTML5 and develop for everything in one go.

Read full topic

item.title: iOS Development - How?
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

CoonHunter:

You can program them in C# via MonoDevelop for iOS and Android, I think WinMobile too

^

However you do need a mac to submit your app to Apple, so most developers just buy some shitty $20 mac on the interwebs and use it only for submitting apps.

Read full topic

item.title: iOS Development - How?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:13, topic:515494”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=633749.msg4280248#msg4280248 date=1365437392]
As christmas said. It doesn’t work.
I wrote some code that would trace everytime you “tapped” anywhere on stage in Flash pro running iOS environment. Nothing traced. Even though I know the code was correct.
[/quote]
Don’t use the trace function, be creative and make your own debug function.[/quote]
The point of the trace was to send some form of text on tap. That’s just a demo. Not really debugging.
If I couldn’t get that to work, what makes you think anything else would work.

Read full topic

item.title: iOS Development - How?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:11, topic:515494”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=633749.msg4280236#msg4280236 date=1365436623]

I think Adobe Flash should be able to make native iOS apps.

It can. But you can’t test them on iDevices without having the developer stuff which is only on Mac.

Just test it in the IDE.

The IDE is ONLY ON THE MAC.

Adoble Flash is for Windows too.
[/quote]
As christmas said. It doesn’t work.
I wrote some code that would trace everytime you “tapped” anywhere on stage in Flash pro running iOS environment. Nothing traced. Even though I know the code was correct.[/quote]
Don’t use the trace function, be creative and make your own debug function.

Read full topic

item.title: iOS Development - How?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

You can get a download link for the IDE (without needing to use apple store) and i’m pretty sure there might be a version available for use on windows (even if its not an official version) otherwise just get a virtual machine.

Read full topic

item.title: iOS Development - How?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:9, topic:515494”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=633749.msg4280235#msg4280235 date=1365436334]

I think Adobe Flash should be able to make native iOS apps.

It can. But you can’t test them on iDevices without having the developer stuff which is only on Mac.

Just test it in the IDE.

The IDE is ONLY ON THE MAC.
[/quote]
Adoble Flash is for Windows too.[/quote]
As christmas said. It doesn’t work.
I wrote some code that would trace everytime you “tapped” anywhere on stage in Flash pro running iOS environment. Nothing traced. Even though I know the code was correct.

Read full topic

item.title: iOS Development - How?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

marcbob:

From what I know, there is no third way you can develop iOS. Android is great because of how open they are and because you can do their stuff in java which most of us on this site are pretty familiar with. I have a macbook pro which I really like but honestly learning Objective-C seems pretty awful.

Yeah, that’s what I was worried about. Cause if I want to make a game, or something for Windows Phone/Android/iOS I’d have to go through the hassle of and getting some form of OSX. I’m glad they removed the apple developer fee

Arcik:

Xcode 4 is an IDE which should work on windows.

Nope. You need the MacStore app to download it.

Read full topic
